answer_html: Where for the last equality we use the substitution \(u=x^2+9\).
answer_latex: Where for the last equality we use the substitution $u=x^2+9$.
question: 3 (a)
sols_html:
We look for an expression in partial fractions of the form:

\(\frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}=\frac{A}{x}+\frac{Bx+C}{x^2+9}\)

Which translates to:

\(x^2-9=Ax^2+9A+Bx^2+Cx\)

From this, we get the following system of equations:

\[\begin{aligned} A+B&=1\\ 9A&=-9\\ C&=0\end{aligned}\]

And so \(A=-1\) and \(B=2\). Then

\(\frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}=\frac{-1}{x}+\frac{2x}{x^2+9}\)

Now we compute the integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}dx &=\int \frac{-dx}{x}+ \int \frac{2xdx}{x^2+9}\\ &=-\ln |x|+\ln |x^2+9|+C\end{aligned}\]

Where for the last equality we use the substitution \(u=x^2+9\).

We want to evaluate the integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx.\end{aligned}\]

As a first step, we split up the integral:

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx = \int\frac{x^2}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx - \int \frac{9}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx\end{aligned}\]

We can evaluate the first integral by canceling a factor of x, and then substitute u= x^2+9, du = 2dx:

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{x^2}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx &= \int \frac{x}{x^2+9}\,dx = \int \frac1{2u}\,du \\ &= \frac12\ln|u| + C = \frac12\ln(x^2+9) + C\end{aligned}\]

The second integral can be evaluated using a partial fraction decomposition

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{-9}{x(x^2+9)} = \frac{A}{x} + \frac{Bx}{x^2+9} + \frac{C}{x^2+9},\end{aligned}\]

which we can solve for \(-9 = A(x^2+9) + Bx^2 + Cx.\) When x = -1, we get -9 = 10A+B-C, when x=1, we get -9 = 10A+B+C. Subtracting the two equations gives C = 0. Finally, when x = 2, we get -9 = 13A + 4B. So 10A + B = 13 A+ 4B, which yields A = -B. Thus -9 = 10A-A = 9A, so that A = -1 and B = 1. Therefore

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{-9}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx = \int \frac{-1}{x}\,dx + \int \frac{x}{x^2+9}\,dx = -\ln|x| + C + \int \frac{x}{x^2+9}\,dx.\end{aligned}\]

We evaluated the last integral earlier in this problem and found \(\int \frac{x}{x^2+9}\,dx = \frac12 \ln(x^2+9).\) So

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{-9}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx = \frac12\ln(x^2+9) - \ln|x| + C,\end{aligned}\]

and therefore the final answer is

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx = \ln(x^2+9) - \ln|x| + C.\end{aligned}\]

We want to evaluate the integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx.\end{aligned}\]

This can be rewritten as

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{2x^2-(x^2+9)}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx &= \int \frac{2x^2}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx - \int \frac{x^2+9}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx \\ &= \int \frac{2x}{x^2+9}\,dx - \int \frac{1}{x}\,dx.\end{aligned}\]

We evaluate the first integral using the substitution u = x^2+9, du = 2xdx, the second integral is just lnx + C. Hence

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{2x^2-(x^2+9)}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx &= \int \frac1{u}\,du - \ln|x| - C \\ &= \ln|u| - \ln|x| - C \\ &= \ln|x^2+9| - \ln|x| - C\end{aligned}\]

Note: Since C is a constant, we can write -C or +D, for D=-C. Either solution is fine.
sols_latex:
We look for an expression in partial fractions of the form:

$\frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}=\frac{A}{x}+\frac{Bx+C}{x^2+9}$

Which translates to:

$x^2-9=Ax^2+9A+Bx^2+Cx$

From this, we get the following system of equations:

\begin{align*}
A+B&=1\\
9A&=-9\\
C&=0
\end{align*}

And so $A=-1$ and $B=2$. Then

$\frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}=\frac{-1}{x}+\frac{2x}{x^2+9}$

Now we compute the integral

\begin{align*}
\int \frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}dx &=\int \frac{-dx}{x}+ \int \frac{2xdx}{x^2+9}\\
&=-\ln |x|+\ln |x^2+9|+C
\end{align*}

Where for the last equality we use the substitution $u=x^2+9$.
sols_raw:
We look for an expression in partial fractions of the form:

<math>
\frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}=\frac{A}{x}+\frac{Bx+C}{x^2+9}
</math>

Which translates to:

<math>
x^2-9=Ax^2+9A+Bx^2+Cx
</math>

From this, we get the following system of equations:

<math>
\begin{align}
A+B&=1\\
9A&=-9\\
C&=0
\end{align}
</math>

And so <math> A=-1 </math> and <math> B=2 </math>. Then
 
<math>
\frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}=\frac{-1}{x}+\frac{2x}{x^2+9}
</math>

Now we compute the integral

<math>
\begin{align}
\int \frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}dx &=\int \frac{-dx}{x}+ \int \frac{2xdx}{x^2+9}\\
&=-\ln |x|+\ln |x^2+9|+C
\end{align}
</math>

Where for the last equality we use the substitution <math> u=x^2+9 </math>.
We want to evaluate the integral

:<math> \int \frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx. </math>

As a first step, we split up the integral:

:<math> \int \frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx = \int \frac{x^2}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx - \int \frac{9}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx </math>

We can evaluate the first integral by canceling a factor of ''x'', and then substitute ''u= x^2+9'', ''du = 2dx'':

:<math>
\begin{align} \int \frac{x^2}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx &= \int \frac{x}{x^2+9}\,dx = \int \frac1{2u}\,du \\
&= \frac12\ln|u| + C = \frac12\ln(x^2+9) + C
\end{align}
</math>

The second integral can be evaluated using a partial fraction decomposition

:<math> \frac{-9}{x(x^2+9)} = \frac{A}{x} + \frac{Bx}{x^2+9} + \frac{C}{x^2+9}, </math>

which we can solve for <math> -9 = A(x^2+9) + Bx^2 + Cx. </math> When ''x = -1'', we get ''-9 = 10A+B-C'', when ''x=1'', we get ''-9 = 10A+B+C''. Subtracting the two equations gives ''C = 0''. Finally, when ''x = 2'', we get ''-9 = 13A + 4B''. So ''10A + B = 13 A+ 4B'', which yields ''A = -B''. Thus ''-9 = 10A-A = 9A'', so that ''A = -1'' and ''B = 1''. Therefore

:<math> \int \frac{-9}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx = \int \frac{-1}{x}\,dx + \int \frac{x}{x^2+9}\,dx = -\ln|x| + C + \int \frac{x}{x^2+9}\,dx.</math>

We evaluated the last integral earlier in this problem and found <math> \int \frac{x}{x^2+9}\,dx = \frac12 \ln(x^2+9).</math> So

:<math> \int \frac{-9}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx = \frac12 \ln(x^2+9) - \ln|x| + C, </math>

and therefore the final answer is

:<math> \int \frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx = \ln(x^2+9) - \ln|x| + C. </math>
We want to evaluate the integral

:<math> \int \frac{x^2-9}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx. </math>

This can be rewritten as

:<math> \begin{align}
\int \frac{2x^2-(x^2+9)}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx &= \int \frac{2x^2}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx - \int \frac{x^2+9}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx \\
&= \int \frac{2x}{x^2+9}\,dx - \int \frac{1}{x}\,dx.
\end{align}
</math>

We evaluate the first integral using the substitution ''u = x^2+9'', ''du = 2xdx'', the second integral is just ''ln|x| + C''. Hence

:<math> \begin{align}
\int \frac{2x^2-(x^2+9)}{x(x^2+9)}\,dx &= \int \frac1{u}\,du - \ln|x| - C \\
&= \ln|u| - \ln|x| - C \\
&= \ln|x^2+9| - \ln|x| - C
\end{align}
</math>

''Note: Since C is a constant, we can write -C or +D, for D=-C. Either solution is fine.''
